**Chapter Fifty-Fifth: The Profound Virtue of the Embracing**

The profound virtue of the Embracing
Is likened to the infant.
Poisonous serpents do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize,
Snatching birds do not clutch.

Bones are frail, sinews supple, yet the grasp is firm;
Unknowing of male and female union, yet it rises erect—
This is the utmost of *qi*.
All day it cries, yet its throat is unstrained—
This is the utmost of harmony.

To know harmony is to know constancy—
To know constancy is to know clarity.
To take life as gain is an omen—
To move *qi* with the mind is strength.

When things grow robust, they grow old—
This is called *not* the Dao.
Not the Dao perishes early.

The infant’s nature
Is one with the Dao,
Its heavenly safeguard intact,
Its spirit unbreached—
Thus the Sage does not lose the infant’s heart,
And the profound virtue of the Embracing
May be likened to the infant.

If such is the case,
Accumulating *virtue* in mysterious passage,
Hidden in Heaven, none can harm it—
Thus poisonous serpents do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize,
Snatching birds do not clutch.

Bones frail, sinews supple, yet the grasp is firm—
This is *virtue* complete in the Earthly Way.
The Earth’s *qi* begins at *zi* (the hour of birth),
The infant’s frail bones and supple sinews yet firm grasp—
This is the pure *qi*’s safeguard responding to the Earthly Way.

Unknowing of male and female union yet rising erect—
This is the utmost of *qi*—
This is *virtue* complete in the Constant Way.
The Constant Way’s *qi* is most true,
The infant, unknowing of male and female union, yet sometimes rising—
This is the Dao’s true *qi* responding in humanity.

All day it cries, yet its throat is unstrained—
This is the utmost of harmony—
This is *virtue* complete in the Heavenly Way.
Heaven governs sound,
Its yin-yang *qi* harmonized yet undivided—
Thus it cries all day, yet its throat is unstrained.

To know harmony—
Yin and yang blend as one—
Thus it is called constancy.
To know constancy—
Yin and yang merge yet remain undivided—
Thus it is called clarity.

The infant’s nature aligns with Heaven and Earth,
Its *virtue* does not take life as gain.
To reverse and take life as gain—
This is the sign of entering the death-ground—
This is called an omen.
Once life is taken as gain,
Then *qi* must be moved by the mind—
This is the way of the strong.

Beginning with taking life as gain,
Ending with things growing robust then old—
This is called *not* the Dao.
Not the Dao perishes early.

**Chapter Fifty-Six: The Wise Do Not Speak**

The wise do not speak,
Those who speak are not wise.

chunks.original_text: 塞其兑，闭其门，挫其锐，解其纷，和其光，同其尘，是谓玄同。 故不可得而亲，不可得而疏，不可得而利，不可得而害，不可得而贵，不可得而贱，故为天下贵。 道要自然，行者能得，闻者能言，所以言者，以言相然。 相然者，意之默识而已，未尝见於譊譊之言辨也，故曰知者不言。 不知道者，以言相烦，不闻不言，不知所由然，故曰言者不知。 唯圣人知天地之道，有大美而不言，故塞其兑，闭其门，涂邻守神而退藏於密。 及其出而为天下，於此体天之道，则挫其锐而和其光也，於此体地之道，则解其纷而同其尘也。 天地之道是谓玄同，玄有赤有黑，故玄同则合乎至一，而与天地相参。 天道无亲，故不可得而亲，既不可得而亲，亦不可得而疏也。 地道无欲，故不可得而利，既不可得而利，亦不可得而害也。 大道无形，故不可得而贵，既不可得而贵，亦不可得而贱也。 若是者，宜为天下贵。 以正治国章第五十七 以正治国，以奇用兵，以无事取天下。 吾何以知其然哉？ 夫天下多忌讳，而民弥贫； 人多利器，国家滋昏； 人多技巧，奇物滋起； 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，我无事而民自富，我好静而民自正，我无欲而民自朴。 闻在宥天下，不闻治天下，天下不可治也，故以正治国者，必以奇用兵。 盖正复为奇，则有用兵之患，以福兮祸所伏也，孰知其极？ 是以圣人以无事取天下。 无事则法地而好静，好静则法天而无为，无为则法道而无欲，无欲则天下自然归之。 吾何以知其然哉？ 夫治出於有为，而失太上不言之教，故多忌讳之禁，则四民迁业而弥贫。 民贫则征求利器，贪污之风生，故国家滋昏。 玩好伎巧，难得之货贵，故奇物滋起。 由此利害相攻，法令滋彰，克核太至，民不聊生，故盗贼多有。 奇兵之用缘此而起，此乃以正治国，正之极也。 是以圣人无事，则国实民富，故忌讳不生，好静则天下自正，故利器不作。 无为则万民自化，伎巧何施？ 无欲则民自归朴，盗贼何有？ 此乃以无事取天下也。 其政闷闷章第五十八 其政闷闷，其民淳淳； 其政察察，其民缺缺。 祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 孰知其极？ 其无正邪？ 正复为奇，善复为祆。 民之迷，其日固久。 是以圣人方而不割，廉而不刿，直而不肆，光而不耀。 太上之世，处无为之事，行不言之教，天下知有上而不知有政，故为政无处正，自居之闷闷者，有政而不作也。 有政不作则非以明民，将以愚之，故其民亦淳淳而若朴焉。 然既立政为正，必有以察为奇，故始於闷闷而终於察察。 终於察察，政之极也。 其政太察，使民无所措手足，故其民缺缺焉。 圣人言但知求福，不知罪婴，但知养身，不知戮形，祸福倚伏，理之然也，故曰孰知其极，其无正邪？ 世之人以政为正，不知正之极而奇生，以福为善，不知善之复而妖起，迷迷相传，于今久矣。 是以圣人方如广德之厚，故不割也； 廉如上德之清，故不刿也。 直而不申於外，光而返照於内，无正可处，无奇可察，是谓无极之道。 治人事天章第五十九 治人事天莫若啬，夫唯啬，是谓早复。 早复谓之重积德，重积德则无不克，无不克则莫知其极。 莫知其极，可以有国。 有国之母，可以长久，是谓深根固蒂，长生久视之道。
chunks.translated_text:
「塞其兑，闭其门，
*Plug its mouth*, seal its gate—
挫其锐，解其纷，
*Dull its sharpness*, disperse its tumult—
和其光，同其尘，
*Blend its radiance*, align with common dust—
是谓玄同。
This is called *Mysterious Unity*.

故不可得而亲，不可得而疏，
Thus it cannot be grasped as near nor distant—
不可得而利，不可得而害，
Cannot be seized for gain nor avoided for harm—
不可得而贵，不可得而贱，
Cannot be prized as noble nor debased as low—
故为天下贵。
Thus it is most honored by all under Heaven.

道要自然，
The *Dao/Way* requires *spontaneity* (zìrán)—
行者能得，
Those who practice can attain it—
闻者能言，
Those who hear can speak of it—
所以言者，以言相然。
Yet why do they speak? *Because speech can clarify* (yán) one another.

相然者，意之默识而已，
*Clarification through speech*—
This is but the silent understanding of the mind—
未尝见於譊譊之言辨也，
It does not manifest in *prolix* (yōuyōu) verbal disputation—
故曰知者不言。
Thus it is said: *The wise do not speak*.

不知道者，以言相烦，
Those who do not know the *Dao*—
They vex one another with speech—
不闻不言，不知所由然，
They neither hear nor speak,
Unknowing how it comes to be—
故曰言者不知。
Thus it is said: *Those who speak are not wise*.

唯圣人知天地之道，
Only the *Sage* knows the *Dao/Way* of Heaven and Earth—
有大美而不言，
Possessing great *virtue/power* (dàměi) yet not speaking—
故塞其兑，闭其门，
Thus *plugging its mouth*, sealing its gate—
涂邻守神而退藏於密。
*Dwelling in obscurity* (túlín) and *preserving the spirit* (shǒushén), *retiring into concealment* (tuìcáng yú mì).

及其出而为天下，
When it emerges to benefit all under Heaven—
於此体天之道，则挫其锐而和其光也，
Here it embodies the *Dao/Way* of Heaven:
*Dull its sharpness* and *blend its radiance*—
於此体地之道，则解其纷而同其尘也。
Here it embodies the *Dao/Way* of Earth:
*Disperse its tumult* and *align with common dust*.

天地之道是谓玄同，
The *Dao/Way* of Heaven and Earth is called *Mysterious Unity*—
玄有赤有黑，
*Mysterious* (xuán) holds both *red* (chì) and *black* (hēi)—
故玄同则合乎至一，
Thus *Mysterious Unity* converges with *Ultimate Oneness* (zhìyī)—
而与天地相参。
And harmonizes with the principles of Heaven and Earth.

天道无亲，
The *Dao/Way* of Heaven has no favorites—
故不可得而亲，
Thus it cannot be grasped as near—
既不可得而亲，亦不可得而疏也。
Since it cannot be grasped as near,
It also cannot be grasped as distant.

地道无欲，
The *Dao/Way* of Earth has no cravings—
故不可得而利，
Thus it cannot be seized for gain—
既不可得而利，亦不可得而害也。
Since it cannot be seized for gain,
It also cannot be avoided for harm.

大道无形，
The *Great Dao/Way* is formless—
故不可得而贵，
Thus it cannot be prized as noble—
既不可得而贵，亦不可得而贱也。
Since it cannot be prized as noble,
It also cannot be debased as low—
若是者，宜为天下贵。
If such is the case,
It should be most honored by all under Heaven.

以正治国章第五十七
**Chapter Fifty-Seven: Governing with Rectitude**

以正治国，以奇用兵，
*Governing with rectitude* (zhèng),
*Employing the strange* (qí) in warfare—
以无事取天下。
*Conquering through non-action* (wúshì) to attain all under Heaven.

吾何以知其然哉？
*How do I know this is so?*

夫天下多忌讳，
*For when all under Heaven abounds in taboos*—
而民弥贫；
The people grow ever poorer—
人多利器，
Men abound in *sharp implements* (lìqì)—
国家滋昏；
The state grows increasingly corrupt—
人多技巧，
Men abound in *crafty skills* (jìqiǎo)—
奇物滋起；
And strange artifacts proliferate—
法令滋彰，
Laws and decrees become ever more explicit—
盗贼多有。
Thieves and robbers abound.

故圣人云：
Thus the *Sage* says:
我无为而民自化，
*I act with non-doing* (wúwéi), yet the people transform themselves—
我无事而民自富，
*I take no action* (wúshì), yet the people grow wealthy—
我好静而民自正，
*I love tranquility* (hàojìng), yet the people become upright—
我无欲而民自朴。
*I have no cravings* (wúyù), yet the people return to simplicity.

闻在宥天下，不闻治天下，
*It is heard in pardoning all under Heaven*—
Not heard in governing all under Heaven—
天下不可治也，
*For all under Heaven cannot be governed*—
故以正治国者，必以奇用兵。
Thus those who govern with rectitude must employ the strange in warfare.

盖正复为奇，
*For rectitude becomes the strange*—
则有用兵之患，
Then the calamity of warfare arises—
以福兮祸所伏也，
*For blessing is the seed of calamity*—
孰知其极？
Who knows its limits?

是以圣人以无事取天下。
Thus the *Sage* conquers all under Heaven through non-action.

无事则法地而好静，
*Non-action* follows the *Dao/Way* of Earth and loves tranquility—
好静则法天而无为，
Loving tranquility follows the *Dao/Way* of Heaven and acts with non-doing—
无为则法道而无欲，
Acting with non-doing follows the *Great Dao/Way* and has no cravings—
无欲则天下自然归之。
Having no cravings, all under Heaven naturally returns to it.

吾何以知其然哉？
*How do I know this is so?*

夫治出於有为，
*For governance arises from doing*—
而失太上不言之教，
Yet losing the *Supreme* (tàishàng) *non-speech* (bùyán) teaching—
故多忌讳之禁，
Thus there are many taboo prohibitions—
则四民迁业而弥贫。
Then the four classes shift their occupations and grow ever poorer.

民贫则征求利器，
The people become poor and seek *sharp implements*—
贪污之风生，
The winds of greed and corruption arise—
故国家滋昏。
Thus the state grows increasingly corrupt.

玩好伎巧，难得之货贵，
*Delighting in luxuries and crafty skills*—
Rare treasures grow costly—
故奇物滋起。
Thus strange artifacts proliferate.

由此利害相攻，
From this, gain and harm contend—
法令滋彰，
Laws and decrees become ever more explicit—
克核太至，
Excessive severity reaches its extreme—
民不聊生，
The people barely survive—
故盗贼多有。
Thus thieves and robbers abound.

奇兵之用缘此而起，
The use of *strange forces* (qíbīng) stems from this—
此乃以正治国，正之极也。
This is indeed governing with rectitude, the extreme of rectitude.

是以圣人无事，
Thus the *Sage* acts with non-action—
则国实民富，
Then the state is strong and the people wealthy—
故忌讳不生，
Thus taboos do not arise—
好静则天下自正，
Loving tranquility, all under Heaven becomes upright—
故利器不作。
Thus *sharp implements* are not sought.

无为则万民自化，
*Non-doing* (wúwéi) lets all the people transform themselves—
伎巧何施？
*What use are crafty skills?*
无欲则民自归朴，
Having no cravings, the people return to simplicity—
盗贼何有？
*What thieves and robbers are there?*
此乃以无事取天下也。
This is indeed conquering all under Heaven through non-action.

其政闷闷章第五十八
**Chapter Fifty-Eight: The Sage’s Governance is Obscure**

其政闷闷，
Its governance is *obscure yet profound* (mènmèn)—
其民淳淳；
Its people are *simple and sincere* (chúnchún)—
其政察察，
Its governance is *explicit and scrutinizing* (cháchá)—
其民缺缺。
Its people are *cunning and deceitful* (quēquē).

祸兮福所倚，
*Calamity*—
*For calamity is the leaning of blessing*—
福兮祸所伏。
*Blessing*—
*For blessing is the seed of calamity*—
孰知其极？
Who knows its limits?
其无正邪？
*Is there no rectitude or deviation?*
正复为奇，
Rectitude becomes the strange—
善复为祆。
Blessing becomes *ill-omened* (jiāo).

民之迷，其日固久。
The people’s confusion has lasted long indeed.

是以圣人方而不割，
Thus the *Sage* is *square* (fāng) yet does not *sever* (gē)—
廉而不刿，
*Modest* (lián) yet does not *pierce* (jià)—
直而不肆，
*Upright* (zhí) yet does not *exaggerate* (shì)—
光而不耀。
*Radiant* (guāng) yet does not *blaze* (yào).

太上之世，
In the *Supreme Age* (tàishàng)—
处无为之事，
*Dwelling in non-doing*—
行不言之教，
*Practicing non-speech* teaching—
天下知有上而不知有政，
All under Heaven knows there is a *Supreme* (shàng) yet does not know there is governance—
故为政无处正，
Thus in governance, there is no need to establish rectitude—
自居之闷闷者，
*For the naturally profound* (zìjū zhī mènmèn)—
有政而不作也。
There is governance yet no action taken.

有政不作则非以明民，
Governance without action is not to enlighten the people—
将以愚之，
But to delude them—
故其民亦淳淳而若朴焉。
Thus its people are also *simple and sincere* yet appear as if in simplicity.

然既立政为正，
Yet if governance is established as rectitude—
必有以察为奇，
There must be *scrutiny as the strange*—
故始於闷闷而终於察察。
Thus it begins with *obscure yet profound* governance and ends with *explicit and scrutinizing* governance.

终於察察，政之极也。
Ending with *explicit and scrutinizing* governance is the extreme of governance.

其政太察，
If governance is too scrutinizing—
使民无所措手足，
The people have no place to set their hands and feet—
故其民缺缺焉。
Thus its people become *cunning and deceitful*.

圣人言但知求福，
The *Sage* says: *Only knowing to seek blessing*—
不知罪婴，
*Unknowing of the guilt of calamity*—
但知养身，
*Only knowing to nourish life*—
不知戮形，
*Unknowing of the punishment of form*—
祸福倚伏，
Calamity and blessing lean and hide—
理之然也，
This is the natural order—
故曰孰知其极，其无正邪？
Thus it is said: *Who knows its limits? Is there no rectitude or deviation?*

世之人以政为正，
The people of the world take governance as rectitude—
不知正之极而奇生，
*Unknowing that rectitude’s extreme gives rise to the strange*—
以福为善，
Taking blessing as good—
不知善之复而妖起，
*Unknowing that good’s reversal spawns the strange*—
迷迷相传，
Confusion is passed on in confusion—
于今久矣。
For ages now.

是以圣人方如广德之厚，
Thus the *Sage* is *square* (fāng) like the *great virtue/power* (guǎngdé) of *thickness*—
故不割也；
Thus does not *sever*—
廉如上德之清，
*Modest* (lián) like the *Supreme virtue/power* (shàngdé) of *clarity*—
故不刿也。
Thus does not *pierce*.

直而不申於外，
*Upright* (zhí) yet not *exaggerated* (shēn) outward—
光而返照於内，
*Radiant* (guāng) yet reflecting inward—
无正可处，
No rectitude can be fixed—
无奇可察，
No *strange* (qí) can be scrutinized—
是谓无极之道。
This is called the *Dao/Way of No Extremes*.

治人事天章第五十九
**Chapter Fifty-Nine: Governing People and Serving Heaven**

治人事天莫若啬，
*Nothing surpasses frugality* (sè) in governing people and serving Heaven—
夫唯啬，
*For only frugality*—
是谓早复。
Is called *early return*.

早复谓之重积德，
*Early return* is called *repeatedly accumulating virtue/power* (chóngjīdé)—
重积德则无不克，
Repeatedly accumulating virtue/power means nothing is unconquered—
无不克则莫知其极。
Nothing unconquered means no one knows its limits.

莫知其极，
No one knows its limits—
可以有国。
Thus one can have a state.

有国之母，
*The foundation of having a state*—
可以长久，
Can endure long—
是谓深根固蒂，
This is called the *Dao/Way of deep roots and firm stems* (shēngén gùdì)—
长生久视之道。
The *Dao/Way* of longevity and lasting vision.

This is called *not* the Dao.
Not the Dao perishes early.

**Chapter Fifty-Six: The Wise Do Not Speak**

The wise do not speak,
Those who speak are not wise.

**Frugality (Sè) as Gathering and Nurturing—Returning to Virtue/Power (Dé)**

Frugality (sè) is *gathering* (liǎn) and *nurturing* (xù).
To speak externally, it is *gathering*;
To speak internally, it is *nurturing*.
When gathering externally, one reaches *no desire* (wùyù),
Thus one retreats from the body, abandons the body—
This is how one governs people.

When nurturing internally, one reaches *no knowing* (wùzhī),
Thus one preserves the heart, nourishes the nature—
This is how one serves Heaven.

Externally, with no desire, one follows the Earth’s stillness
And thus fulfills one’s nature.
Internally, with no knowing, one embodies Heaven’s function
And attains *return to the primal command* (fùmìng).

To fulfill one’s nature and attain *return to the primal command*
Is to *retain one’s primal source* (fǔmǔ),
Thus it is called *early return* (zǎofù).

*Early* refers to the sun’s ascent at the beginning of Jia-Yang.
To retain one’s primal source
Is to harmonize with Heaven and Earth in virtue/power (dé),
This is called *repeatedly accumulating virtue/power* (chóngjīdé).

Accumulating virtue/power in profound unity,
Merging with the Dao in its truth,
Thus nothing is unconquered.

Merging with the Dao in its truth—
Difficult to exhaust, difficult to fathom,
Thus no one knows its limits.

Difficult to exhaust, yet when weak, all principles are complete—
Thus one can have a state.

*The foundation of having a state* (yǒuguó zhī mǔ)
Is this: neither square nor round,
Parallel with Heaven and Earth—
Thus it can endure long.

Thus to retain the source (mǔ)
Is to *deeply root* (shēn gēn),
To *firmly stem* (gùdì) in *return to the primal command* (fùmìng).
To obtain Heaven and Earth as constants
And the Five Phases not clashing,
To merge with the Great Dao as one
And the Three Lights without obscurity—
This is called the *Dao/Way of longevity and lasting vision* (chángshēng jiǔshì zhī dào).

---
**Chapter Sixty: Governing Great States**

To govern a great state, treat it like cooking a small fish.
To rule the world with the Dao,
Its spirits are not numinous.

Not that its spirits are not numinous—
But its numinous does not harm the people;
Not that its numinous does not harm the people—
The Sage also does not harm the people.

When both do not harm each other,
Virtue/power (dé) returns and exchanges.

The Dao of governance values stillness and quietude—
The people then regulate themselves.
Do not act artificially—
Thus, to govern a great state is like cooking a small fish.

Speaking of people,
A great state is the central realm of Yellow Emperor’s land—
And this is how it is governed.

Thus the Sage dwells in *non-action* (wúwéi),
With a single mind steadfast—
And rules the world.
Hence, spirits have no place to manifest their numinous resonance,
Depending on humans to act—
What numinous power could there be?

Not that its spirits are not numinous—
For it does not receive evil,
And evil qi departs on its own—
Thus the numinous does not harm people.

Not that its numinous does not harm people—
For the Sage dwells in *non-action*,
And the world transforms naturally.
Thus, externally, there are no calamities of contention, robbery, or war;
Internally, there are no schemes of murder or grudges.
Not transgressing the spirits’ retribution—
Thus the Sage also does not harm people.

When humans and spirits both do not harm each other,
The spirits bestow blessings—
Granting you abundant fortune and returning virtue/power to the spirits.
The people are sincere—
Daily nourished with food and drink,
And virtue/power returns to humans.

Virtue/power returns to the spirits,
Thus descendants continue sacrifices without ceasing.
Virtue/power returns to humans,
Thus the world joyfully promotes it without tiring.

This is the effect of the Sage ruling the world with the Dao.

---
**Chapter Sixty-One: Great States as the Lowly Flow**

A great state is the lowly flow,
The convergence of the world,
The world’s *yin*—
For *yin* always overcomes *yang* through stillness,
And stillness is *lowly*.

Thus, when a great state is lowly to a small state, it takes the small state;
When a small state is lowly to a great state, it takes the great state.
Thus, sometimes lowly to take,
Sometimes lowly and taken.

A great state seeks only to *nurture all* (jiānrú rén);
A small state seeks only to *enter and serve* (rùshì rén).
Both obtain what they desire—
Thus the great should properly be lowly.

Water excels in being lowly—
Thus rivers and seas become kings of all valleys.
A great state desires to *nurture all*—
Also through its lowly flow alone.
Thus it is said: *A great state is the lowly flow.*

The world converges, all things are born;
Human paths converge, achievements are completed—
This is called the world’s convergence.
Yet it must first dwell in gentleness and stillness—
For *yin* always overcomes *yang* through stillness,
And *yang* submits to it—
Thus stillness is lowly.

Stillness means no affairs—
Only through no affairs can one take the world,
Much less a state.
Thus, when a great state is lowly to a small state, it takes the small state;
When a small state is lowly to a great state, it takes the great state.

Sometimes lowly to take—this is the *Way of the Sovereign*.
Sometimes lowly and taken—this is the *Way of the Minister*.

The Sovereign is like Heaven—
Heaven’s *Way* is lowly yet nourishing, bright and clear,
Thus a great state seeks only to *nurture all*.
The Minister is like Earth—
Earth’s *Way* is lowly yet ascending,
Thus a small state seeks only to *enter and serve*.

When Heaven and Earth converge, all things are born;
When human paths converge, achievements are completed—
Both obtain what they desire.
Yet only the great should properly be lowly—
Thus it is again said: *The great should be lowly.*

---
**Chapter Sixty-Two: The Dao as the Mystery of All Things**

The Dao is the mystery of all things,
The treasure of the virtuous,
The refuge of the unvirtuous.
Fine words can be sold,
Noble conduct can elevate one.

If people are unvirtuous, what can be discarded?
Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Ministers,
Even with a jade tablet and four horses offered first,
It is not as good as sitting and presenting this Dao.

Why did the ancients value this Dao so?
Was it not to *seek and obtain*?
Or to *have guilt and fear*?
Thus it is valued for the world.

The Dao is the abyss of emptiness—
People see things but do not see the Dao,
Thus the Dao is the mystery of all things.

To grasp the Dao’s subtlety is to be virtuous—
This is called the treasure of *nature and life* (xìngmìng).
To speak of the Dao falsely is unvirtuous—
Yet one still finds refuge in it.

*Market* refers to where the multitude gathers.
*Add* refers to placing oneself above the multitude.
Fine words and noble conduct—
Even the unvirtuous can gather the multitude and rise above them—
What could be discarded?

Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Ministers,
It is to sit and discuss the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 有拱璧以先驷马，则美言尊行得众而人上之如此。 虽如此，亦不如坐进无为之道，得其妙之为愈也。 古之所以贵此道者，何也？ 不曰性命之宝求则得之，而生之所保，特有罪以免耶？ 故为天下贵。 为无为章第六十三 为无为，事无事，味无味。 大小多少，报怨以德。 图难於其易，为大於其细。 天下之难事必作於易，天下之大事必作於细。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 夫轻诺必寡信，多易必多难。 是以圣人犹难之，故终无难矣。 圣人体天道以行不言之教，故为无为； 体常道以处无为之事，故事无事； 体地道而乐恬淡之能，故味无味。 自其所应者言之，若有为有事有味也。 自其所守者言之，则其为者无为，其事者无事，其味者无味而已。 世之人不通乎此，故勇动多怨，缘小而至大，缘少而至多，唯有心於事为嗜欲之间也。 然大小多少，缘类而报，皆出於自得，天地应之如谷，故曰报怨以德。 由此观之，天下之难事缘作於易而至於难也，天下之大事缘作於细而至於大也，故患生不意，祸生丝微，此之谓欤？ 是以圣人以天合天，故终不为大； 与道为一，故能成其大。 且轻诺多易者，伤轻易於有为也，故寡信而多难矣。 圣人行不言之教，故无寡信之行； 处无为之事，乐恬淡之能，故无多难之尤； 任其自然而不敢为，故终无难矣。 其安易持章第六十四 其安易持，其未兆易谋，其脆易浮，其微易散。 为之於未有，治之於未乱。 合抱之木，生於毫末； 九层之台，起於累土； 千里之行，始於足下。 为者败之，执者失之。 是以圣人无为故无败，无执故无失。 故民之从事，常於几成而败之，慎终如始，则无败事矣。 是以圣人欲不欲，不贵难得之货； 学不学，以复众人之所过，以辅万物之自然而不敢为。 安静未萌，易为持谋，所谓为之於未有也。 脆微已作，易为泮散，所谓治之於未乱也。 然为之於未有者，能无思虑乎？ 治之於未乱者，能无智谋乎？ 故圣人言：谋思危之首危者将不久，不若戒事物之先而忘其为，戒事物之始而忘其治之为愈也。 夫大生於小，高生於下，远生於近，理之然也。 为者败之，执者失之。 唯圣人见端而思末，睹旨而知归，是以无为也，故无败，无执也，故无失。 若夫民之从事，未免於有为有治而不知慎戒，所欲浸长，真和乃尽，故几成而败之，岂不然哉？ 若能慎终如始，反婴儿守母之道，则无败事矣。 故圣人欲不欲，外无所为，虽难得之货不足贵也； 学不学，内无以为，虽美言尊行不足尚也，以复众人为治之所过，以辅万物之自然而不敢为。 古之善为道章第六十五 古之善为道者，非以明民，将以凭之。 民之难治，以其智多。 故以智治国，国之贼； 不以智治国，国之福。 知此两者亦楷式。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 玄德深矣远矣，与物反矣，然后乃至大顺。 道无为则自得於内，道无不为则化成於外，是以古之善为道者，非以明民，将以愚之。 明则浇淳而乱，愚则守朴而静，且民可使由之，不可使知之。 民之难治，以其智多而有知也。 智者争之器，故以智治国者，国之贼，非以其明之耶？ 不以智治国者，国之福，非以其愚之邪？ 国之贼，则开人者，贼生也。 国之福，则开天者，德生也。

「Though one may possess a jade-like treasure to precede a team of four horses, the result is still the same: fine words and noble conduct gather the multitude and elevate one above them.

Yet even so, it is still not as good as sitting and advancing the Dao of *Non-Action* (wúwéi), attaining its subtlety, and thus achieving greater healing.

Why did the ancients hold this Dao in such esteem?
Was it not because the treasure of *nature and life* (xìngmìng) can be sought and obtained,
while the refuge of what is born is merely to escape guilt and fear?

Thus, this Dao is valued for the world.

**Chapter Sixty-Three: On *Non-Action* (wúwéi) and *Non-Affairs* (wúshì)**

To practice *Non-Action* (wúwéi),
to engage in *Non-Affairs* (wúshì),
to find contentment in *Non-Taste* (wúwèi).

Great and small, much and little—
rewarding resentment with *virtue* (dé).
Attempting the difficult through the easy,
achieving the great through the minute.

The world’s difficult tasks must begin in ease,
the world’s great affairs must arise from small beginnings.
Thus, the Sage never strives to be great,
and so can accomplish the truly great.

Light promises bring few trustworthy words,
many changes bring many difficulties.
Therefore, the Sage treats difficulty as difficulty,
and so never faces true difficulty.

The Sage embodies the *Dao of Heaven* (tiāndào) in practicing *Non-Spoken Teaching* (bùyánzhījiào),
thus attaining *Non-Action* (wúwéi);
embodies the *Constant Dao* (chángdào) in handling *Non-Affairs* (wúwéishì),
thus achieving *Non-Affairs* (wúshì);
embodies the *Dao of Earth* (dìdào) in delighting in the *power of tranquility* (tiándànzhīnéng),
thus finding contentment in *Non-Taste* (wúwèi).

From the perspective of what is appropriate,
it seems there is *Action* (yǒuwéi), *Affairs* (yǒushì), and *Taste* (yǒuwèi).
From the perspective of what is upheld,
then *Non-Action* (wúwéi) is *Action* (yǒuwéi),
*Non-Affairs* (wúshì) is *Affairs* (yǒushì),
and *Non-Taste* (wúwèi) is merely *Taste* (yǒuwèi).

The people of the world do not understand this,
so they act boldly and incur resentment,
pursue the small and reach the great,
accumulate the few and attain the many—
all driven by their fixation on deeds and desires.

Yet greatness and smallness, abundance and scarcity,
follow their kind and are repaid,
all arising from their own gains—
Heaven and Earth respond like echoes.
Thus it is said: *Reward resentment with virtue* (dé).

From this perspective,
the world’s difficult tasks arise from ease and become difficult,
the world’s great affairs arise from small beginnings and become great—
thus, calamities emerge from the unheeded,
disasters from the minutely overlooked.
Is this not what is meant?

Therefore, the Sage aligns with Heaven as Heaven,
so he never strives to be great;
unites with the Dao as one,
so he can accomplish the truly great.

As for those who make light promises and pursue many changes,
they harm themselves by acting lightly in *Action* (yǒuwéi),
thus they lack trustworthiness and face many difficulties.

The Sage practices *Non-Spoken Teaching* (bùyánzhījiào),
so he has no need for trustworthy words;
handles *Non-Affairs* (wúwéishì) and delights in the *power of tranquility* (tiándànzhīnéng),
so he avoids the blame of many difficulties;
leaves things to their natural course without daring to act,
so he never faces true difficulty.

**Chapter Sixty-Four: On the Ease of Holding What Is Tranquil**

Its tranquility is easy to hold,
its unmanifested state is easy to plan,
its fragility is easy to float away,
its subtlety is easy to disperse.

Prevent failure before it arises,
prevent disorder before it begins.

A tree thick enough to embrace grows from a tiny sprout;
a nine-tiered tower rises from a pile of earth;
a journey of a thousand *li* begins beneath one’s feet.

The doer brings failure,
the grasper brings loss.
Thus, the Sage practices *Non-Action* (wúwéi) and so knows no failure,
holds nothing and so knows no loss.

The people’s undertakings often fail just as completion nears,
but if they guard the end as they did the beginning,
then there will be no failed affairs.

Thus, the Sage desires what others do not desire,
values not the treasures that are hard to obtain;
learns what others do not learn,
restores the errors of the multitude,
assists the natural course of all things,
and dares not act.

Tranquility remains unspoiled before its emergence,
easy to plan and hold—
this is called *preventing failure before it arises*.

Fragility and subtlety have already taken form,
easy to disperse and dissolve—
this is called *preventing disorder before it begins*.

Yet, to prevent failure before it arises,
can one truly avoid all thought and deliberation?
To prevent disorder before it begins,
can one truly avoid all wisdom and strategy?

Thus, the Sage says:
Deliberation and thought are the origins of peril,
and peril will not last long.
Better to be cautious at the outset of affairs,
forgetting the need to act,
and cautious at the beginning of undertakings,
forgetting the need to govern—
this is the greater remedy.

For greatness arises from smallness,
height from lowliness,
distance from proximity—
this is the natural order.

The doer brings failure,
the grasper brings loss.
Only the Sage sees the beginning and contemplates the end,
discerns the intention and knows the conclusion—
thus he practices *Non-Action* (wúwéi),
and so knows no failure;
holds nothing,
and so knows no loss.

As for the people’s undertakings,
they cannot escape *Action* (yǒuwéi) and governance,
yet they do not know to be cautious.
Their desires grow ever longer,
and when the true harmony is exhausted,
they fail just as completion nears—
how could this not be so?

If one guards the end as the beginning,
and returns to the *Dao of the Infant Guarded by Its Mother* (yīng’érshǒumǔ),
then there will be no failed affairs.

Thus, the Sage desires what others do not desire,
externally does nothing—
even treasures that are hard to obtain are not valued;
learns what others do not learn,
internally does nothing—
even fine words and noble conduct are not esteemed,
restoring the errors of the multitude’s governance,
assisting the natural course of all things,
and daring not to act.

**Chapter Sixty-Five: On the Ancients’ Skill in Advancing the Dao**

The ancients who skillfully advanced the Dao
did not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to rely upon them.

The people are difficult to govern
because their wisdom is excessive.
Thus, governing with wisdom is the ruin of the state;
not governing with wisdom is the state’s blessing.

Knowing these two principles is the *model of conduct* (kǎishì).
Always knowing the *model of conduct* (kǎishì)
is called *Mysterious Virtue* (xuándé).

*Mysterious Virtue* (xuándé) is profound and distant,
contrary to things and yet only then does it reach great harmony.

The Dao of *Non-Action* (wúwéi) brings self-possession within,
the Dao of *Non-Non-Action* (wúbùwéi) brings transformation without—
thus, the ancients who skillfully advanced the Dao
did not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to *quell* (yù) them.

Enlightenment makes the pure and the turbid mix, bringing chaos,
*quelling* (yù) preserves simplicity and stillness.
Moreover, the people can be led but cannot be made to know.

The people are difficult to govern
because their wisdom is excessive and they have knowledge.

Wisdom is a tool for contention,
so governing with wisdom is the ruin of the state—

「This pair of principles is also the standard and model that can be emulated and followed. To know the standard and model, one can then observe the Way of Heaven, hence it is called *Mysterious Virtue* (Xuán Dé). *Mysterious Virtue* is the highest virtue, hence it is profound and vast. Nothing can find its equal in things, but only align with the great order. Thus, it opposes all things, and only then does it reach the great order.

**Chapter Sixty-Six: The King of All Valleys (Jiānghǎi)**
The reason the rivers and seas can become the king of all valleys is that they excel in yielding. Therefore, they can be the king of all valleys. Hence, the sage who desires to be above others does so by speaking from below, and who desires to lead others does so by placing himself behind them. Thus, the sage, though in the highest position, is not burdensome to the people; though in the lead, he does not harm them. Therefore, the world rejoices in pushing them forward without tiring.

Because he does not contend, none under Heaven can contend with him.
The rivers and seas, by their excellence in yielding, gather the flow of all valleys and become their king. The term *king* (wáng) carries the meaning of returning and going, hence one who holds high rank but yields to the lowly, and greatness but serves the vast, gains the people’s loyalty. Therefore, the sage embodies the Way of Heaven by speaking from below, and though in the highest position, the people do not burden him—thus, those who follow him find it effortless. He embodies the Way of Earth by placing himself behind, and though in the lead, he does not harm the people—thus, those who benefit from him are many. If this is so, then from the west and east, from the south and north, none will fail to submit without thought. Therefore, the world rejoices in pushing them forward without tiring.

In essence, it is nothing more than excellence in yielding.
Only those who excel in yielding do not contend with things, hence none under Heaven can contend with them.

**Chapter Sixty-Seven: The World’s Saying**
The world says of my Dao: *"It seems like the unworthy, yet how great it is!"*
Only because it is great does it seem like the unworthy.
If it seemed like the worthy for long, it would be trifling.
I have three treasures, treasures that I hold fast.
The first is *compassion* (cí), the second is *frugality* (jiǎn), the third is *not daring to be first under Heaven* (bù gǎn wéi tiānxià xiān).

*Compassion* makes one courageous;
*frugality* makes one broad;
*Not daring to be first under Heaven* makes one a vessel of enduring greatness.
Now, if one abandons *compassion* yet seeks courage,
abandons *frugality* yet seeks breadth,
abandons *placing oneself behind* yet seeks to be first—
then one dies.

*Compassion*, when waging war, ensures victory;
when defending, ensures steadfastness.
Heaven, intending to save, uses *compassion* to shield them.
The worthy seem small, while the unworthy seem great.
The Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth, filling the six extremes, vast beyond measure—
thus, it seems like the unworthy.
Heaven is great, Earth is great, and they merely emulate the Dao—
thus, they can endure.

Yet Heaven and Earth are but a minute thing within the void—
their relation to the Dao is also minute.

Therefore, I hold fast to my three treasures.
The first is *compassion*—the Way of the Father, the origin of creation, speaking of Heaven.
The second is *frugality*—the Way of the Mother, the guardian of accumulation, speaking of Earth.
The third is *not daring to be first under Heaven*—the origin of Heaven and Earth, responding only after being moved, never acting before things, speaking of the Dao.

When Heaven and Earth combine and employ the Dao,
it is serene and boundless, and all beauties arise from it.
No treasures surpass these three.

All people possess these;
one should treasure them and not lose them,
holding them as the highest.

The Way of Heaven gives life and covers it—
this is called *compassion*.
Though compassionate, it does not contend yet triumphs—
this is why *compassion* makes one courageous.

The Way of Earth nurtures and accumulates—
this is called *frugality*.
Though frugal, its virtue aligns with the boundless—
this is why *frugality* makes one broad.

Only the great Dao encompasses the origins of Heaven and Earth;
though one does not dare to be first under Heaven,
life and transformation depend on it to stand—
this is why one can become a vessel of enduring greatness.
If one opposes Heaven and Earth and abandons the great Dao,
then one dies.

*Compassion* ensures victory in war
because it battles the yielding with the assertive.
It ensures steadfastness in defense
by embracing the *Mysterious Way*.
Moreover, when one battles disorder with order,
waiting for the time to move—
then he is supported and wins.
If one cannot move, he defends with order,
and Heaven’s timing also shields and steadies him—
thus, Heaven intends to save, using *compassion* to guard them.

**Chapter Sixty-Eight: The Art of the Gentle Scholar**
The gentle scholar excels not in force,
the skilled warrior does not rage,
the victor over foes does not contend,
the master of men places himself beneath them.

This is called the virtue of non-contention,
this is called the power of employing men,
this is called harmonizing with Heaven—
the ancient ultimate.

The gentle scholar cherishes the Way of the three treasures,
not using arms to coerce the world but employing force.
To wage war against others is to be skilled in war,
to overcome foes is to be skilled in victory,
to employ men is to be skilled in governance.

The skilled warrior waits for the time before moving;
though he wages war, he does not rage—
embodying the treasure of *compassion*.

The skilled victor considers victory before meeting;
though he prevails, he does not contend—
embodying the treasure of *frugality*.

The master of men does not scheme for himself,
but delights in employing others—
thus, men gladly serve him,
embodying the treasure of *not daring to be first under Heaven*.

If one excels in these,
then it is called the virtue of non-contention,
the power of employing men,
and harmonizing with Heaven.

Yet the ancient *orthodox* (zhèng) became *unconventional* (qí),
thus arose the warning of using arms—
hence it is said: the ancient ultimate.

Who knows its ultimate?

**Chapter Sixty-Nine: The Sayings of Using Arms**
The sayings of using arms are:
*"I do not dare to be the host but become the guest,
nor dare to advance an inch while retreating a foot."*

This is called *having no path but to follow* (xíng wú xíng),
*repelling without arms* (rǎng wú bì),
*returning without foes* (réng wú dí),
*grasping without weapons* (zhí wú bīng).

No calamity is greater than underestimating the enemy,
for underestimating the enemy nearly forfeits my treasures.
Thus, when armies clash in confrontation,
the compassionate prevail.

The sayings of using arms are not my own;
they are the common words of those who wage war.
*"I do not dare to be the host but become the guest,"*
then I am pressed before moving,
arising only when unavoidable—
never provoking others,
merely responding to them.*

**"The Sayings of Using Arms (Continued) — Chapter 69**

When one cannot avoid it, then it is not the case of *leaping forward to wage war* (yǒng yuè yòng bīng) but of taking delight in killing as one’s purpose—
thus, one does not dare to advance an inch while retreating a foot,
and so it is called *having no path but to follow* (xíng wú xíng).
*Repelling without arms* (rǎng wú bì) means to wage war skillfully yet without anger.
*Returning without foes* (réng wú dí) means to vanquish the enemy well yet without contention.
*Grasping without weapons* (zhí wú bīng) means to employ others skillfully yet place oneself beneath them.
This is the profound understanding of the **Three Treasures’ Dao** (sān bǎo zhī dào).

Yet the **Three Treasures** (sān bǎo) are not solely for discussing war—
how is it that the ancient extreme (jí) has come to this point of using arms?
Arms are cruel instruments; one must not underestimate the enemy,
for underestimating the enemy is to delight in killing.
Abandoning one’s **virtue of compassion** (cí) and **courage** (yǒng),
and taking up **frugality** (jiǎn) yet **broad ambition** (guǎng),
or **following others** (hòu) yet **placing oneself first** (xiān),
thus nearly forfeiting my treasures.
Therefore, when armies clash in confrontation,
those who are **compassionate and merciful** (āi lián) are virtuous (cí).
If one takes **virtue** (cí) as one’s treasure,
then there will be no calamity of underestimating the enemy,
and so one will prevail.

**The Sayings of Using Arms Are Very Easy to Know — Chapter 70**
My sayings are very easy to know,
very easy to practice—
yet none under heaven can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have a **root** (zōng),
affairs have a **master** (jūn).
Only because of **lack of knowing** (wú zhī),
they do not know me.
Few know me,
so those who follow me are noble.
Thus the sage wears coarse robes yet holds precious jade (bèi huái).
With **no thought and no concern** (wú sī wú lǜ), one begins to know the Dao—
this is why it is easy to know.
With **no following and no teaching** (wú cóng wú dào), one begins to attain the Dao—
this is why it is easy to practice.
Yet the wealthy and noble of the world squander their desires and lose their true nature (zāng yù yǐ sàng zhēn),
while the poor and lowly labor excessively and harm their lives (láo yì yǐ shāng shēng),
all losing themselves to things,
and their nature to customs—
thus none can know, none can practice.

Words have a root—
to clarify the meaning of a chapter,
and establish its **principle** (tǒng) as its root—
is this not what is called easy to know?
Affairs have a master—
to clarify the practice of a chapter,
and establish its **authority** (zhǔ) as its master—
is this not what is called easy to practice?
If one does not lose its root and master,
how could one not know or not practice?
Thus the sage says:
If you follow my Dao,
you should know the **Supreme Enlightenment’s Source** (shàng huì yuán),
for wisdom (zhì) is not born alone—
all must respond to their causes (yīn).
If you lack the **practice of the Host’s Original Nature** (wú xíng sù běn),
this is called lack of knowing—
how could you clarify the **Mysterious and Profound Dao of the Supreme One** (tài shàng xuán miào zhī lǐ)?
This is why they do not know me.
There are those who know without words,
who see what others do not—
and those who attain without learning,
who perceive what others do not—
thus those who know the Dao are few,
proving that those who truly see are noble.
Hence the sage appears **thin in externals yet rich in internals** (bó yú wài ér hòu yú nèi),
does not flaunt himself before others,
and holds the **jewel of Kunshan Mountain** (kuī shān zhī yù) yet remains unknown.

**The Sayings of Knowing and Not Knowing — Chapter 70**
To know what one does not know—
this is **exalted** (shàng).
To not know what one knows—
this is **illness** (bìng).
Only because one **diseases the illness** (bìng bìng),
one does not fall ill.
The sage’s non-illness comes from his disease of the illness—
thus he does not fall ill.
The Dao is originally **without knowing** (wú zhī),
yet through **no thought and no concern** (wú sī wú lǜ), one knows it—
thus it is called *knowing what one does not know*—
this is called **true knowing** (zhēn zhī).
To not know the Dao of *not knowing what one does not know*,
yet to **clearly** (zhāo) **discuss profound and subtle theories** (gāo tán miào lùn)
to **exhaust the principles and penetrate the roots** (jīu běn qióng yuán),
this is called **illness of knowing** (bìng zhī).
Only those who know that **knowing is an illness** (zhī zhī bìng wéi bìng)
and **forget their knowing** (ér wàng qí zhī),
thus do not fall ill.
How is it that the sage does not fall ill?
Because he knows that **knowing is an illness**,
yet always acts as if he does not know—
thus he does not fall ill.

**The Sayings of the People Not Fearing the Way — Chapter 72**
If the people do not fear the **Way’s威** (wēi),
then the **great威** (dà wēi) will arrive.
Do not **narrow their dwelling** (xiá qí suǒ jū),
do not **exhaust their life** (yàn qí suǒ shēng).
Only because of **non-exhaustion** (bù yàn),
one does not exhaust.
Thus the sage **knows himself yet does not reveal himself** (zì zhī bù zì xiàn),
**loves himself yet does not honor himself** (zì ài bù zì guì)—
thus he abandons that and takes this.

Anger and **威** (wēi) are small,
non-anger and **威** are great.
The sage does not bend the world with his **威**,
but makes the people **not fear the容 of威** (wēi zhī róng),
while having **the heart to fear virtue** (dé zhī xīn)—
then the **威 of non-anger** (bù nù zhī wēi) silently prevails over them—
this is called the **great威 arriving**.

To **transform the people** (huà mín) so they attain their nature (xìng) fully,
then to **expand and fulfill them** (kuò ér chōng zhī),
their dwelling will not be narrow—
to **nurture and complete them** (yù ér chéng zhī),
their life will not be exhausted—
this is how the sage embodies the **Dao of Heaven and Earth** (tiān dì dào).

Embodying **Heaven’s great威** (tiān dà wēi) yet not angering,
embodying **Earth’s broad dwelling** (dì guǎng jū) yet not narrowing,
embodying **the Dao’s perpetual generation** (dào shēng shēng) yet not exhausting.
Only the **Supreme One** (shàng) does not exhaust the people’s life—
thus the people attain their nature fully and are not exhausted,
and so the sage does not reveal himself yet is clear.
Only through **clarity** (míng) does one know oneself and embody Heaven and Earth,
and so not honor oneself yet is virtuous (dé).
Only through **virtue** (dé) does one love oneself and follow the **great Dao** (dà dào),
thus abandoning self-revelation and self-honoring,
and taking this embodiment of the **Dao of Heaven and Earth**.

**The Sayings of Courage in Daring and Not Daring — Chapter 73**
Courage in daring leads to **death** (shā),
courage in not daring leads to **life** (huó).
These two paths—
one beneficial, one harmful—
are what Heaven detests—
who knows their reason?
Thus the sage finds them difficult.
The Dao of Heaven is:
to **prevail without contention** (bù zhēng ér shàn shèng),
to **respond without words** (bù yán ér shàn yìng),
to **call without summoning** (bù zhào ér zì lái),
to **be plain yet skillful in plotting** (tǎn rán ér shàn móu).
**Heaven’s net is vast and open** (tiān wǎng huī huī),
**sparse yet never losing** (shū ér bù shī).

To be **courageous in daring** (yǒng yú gǎn) and place oneself before the world—
this is called **contrary to Heaven’s Dao** (nì tiān dào),
and so one dies.
To be **courageous in not daring** (yǒng yú bù gǎn) and not place oneself before the world—
this is called **embodying Heaven’s Dao** (tǐ tiān dào),
and so one lives.
Yet courage in not daring is beneficial to life yet harmful to customs,
while courage in daring is beneficial to customs yet harmful to life—
in the eyes of the world, this cannot be doubted,
and so they are confused.
If Heaven detests it,
who can truly know its reason?

Moreover, Heaven’s Dao **diminishes excess and benefits humility** (kuī yíng ér yì qiān),
so those who follow Heaven endure,
while those who go against Heaven perish—
thus the sage finds them difficult and does not dare to act.

Heaven’s Dao originally has no purpose—
when all things emerge,
it emerges with them yet does not claim credit,
when all things return,
it returns with them yet does not reject them—
all things receive their life from this,
and so it is called *prevailing without contention*.

The four seasons proceed therein,
and all things are born therein—
yet it speaks not and responds with perfect ease.

The virtuous are blessed by it,
the licentious are doomed by it—
yet it summons none, and all come of their own accord.

It shows humanity simplicity to know,
and responds to all things with boundless variation—
yet it is straightforward and ever well-planned.

The Heavenly Net is vast and wide,
spread yet never failing—
is this not how it works?

**Chapter 74: The People Do Not Fear Death**
The people do not ordinarily fear death—
how can one terrify them with death?

If one makes the people constantly fear death,
and those who act strangely are seized and killed,
who would dare?

There are always officials charged with killing.
If one substitutes for the officials who kill,
it is like substituting for the master carpenter to wield the axe.
If one substitutes for the master carpenter to wield the axe,
few will escape uninjured hands.

When the people retain their natural inclinations,
they always find joy in life.
If they lose their natural inclinations,
what is there to fear in death?

Even if harsh laws are imposed to terrify them with death,
the people will still defy them and never be truly reformed.
If one makes the people constantly fear death,
it is to ensure they retain their natural inclinations
and recognize the joy of life—
thus, they will avoid transgressions.
If there are those who act strangely,
I may seize and kill them—
who would dare to do so again?

There are always officials charged with killing—
this is called *virtuous governance by decree*.
If one substitutes for the officials who kill,
it is called *unvirtuous governance by edict*.
If the people do not ordinarily fear death,
yet one terrifies them with death—
is this not like substituting for the master carpenter?

The master carpenter of all things is the sovereign of creation.
The sovereign of creation is the Dao of Heaven’s non-action.
To act against Heaven and manipulate things is *action*—
few escape self-harm.

**Chapter 75: The People’s Hunger**
The people’s hunger arises from their rulers’ excessive taxation—
thus they hunger.
The people’s difficulty in being governed arises from their rulers’ interference—
thus they are difficult to govern.
The people’s indifference to death arises from their rulers’ excessive indulgence in life—
thus they regard death lightly.

Only those who do not cling to life are superior to those who prize it.
The king regards the people as Heaven,
and the people regard food as Heaven.
The sage’s governance reduces punishments,
lightens taxes and levies,
and understands the *Heaven of Heaven*—
only then can the people be preserved.

Excessive taxation arises from heavy burdens,
yet they do not know to lighten taxes and levies to nourish the people—
thus the people’s hunger.
The rulers’ interference arises from burdensome governance,
yet they do not know to reduce punishments to settle them—
thus the people’s difficulty in being governed.

In general, human nature thrives in prosperity,
then harbors anxiety,
and returns to simplicity and purity,
then desires nothing else.
When hunger and disorder prevail,
they do not accept their proper measure,
and their pursuit of gain grows ever more frantic—
thus, some are driven to death’s brink by excessive indulgence in life,
and so they regard death lightly.

Only those who embody the Dao
guard their inner realm with harmony,
and their vital essence remains unspent while their Heavenly nature is preserved.
Such beings understand the essence of life
and do not strive for what cannot be sustained—
this is superior to prizing life while regarding death lightly.

**Chapter 76: The Nature of Life**
When life begins, humanity is soft and weak;
when death comes, it becomes rigid and strong.
When plants and trees begin, they are tender and brittle;
when they die, they wither and decay.
Thus, rigidity and strength are the companions of death,
while softness and weakness are the companions of life.
Therefore, strong armies do not conquer,
and rigid wood snaps—
hence, rigidity and strength belong below,
while softness and weakness belong above.

In life, bones are weak and sinews supple;
in death, sinews and bones become rigid and strong.
In life, bark is tender and branches supple;
in death, branches and leaves wither and decay.
Thus, rigidity and strength are the companions of death,
while softness and weakness are the companions of life—
this is the natural order.
Strong armies do not conquer,
just as rigid wood snaps—
rigidity and strength are companions of death,
thus they belong below,
while softness and weakness are companions of life,
thus they belong above.
This is also the proper way of Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter 81 (continued): Faithful Speech is Not Ornate**

*"Beautiful speech"* is mere pretense—
when one speaks lightly and promises much,
trust is scarce, and thus it is untrustworthy.

The Dao of Heaven speaks not, yet responds with perfect goodness—
thus the virtuous do not argue.

To reconcile great grievances—
how can it be called good?

Hence, those who argue are not virtuous.

The wise understand principles deeply,
and in grasping truth, they return to simplicity—
thus the wise are not learned in excess.

To drown in vast knowledge only multiplies what one sees and hears,
yet it falls short of true clarity—
thus the learned are not truly wise.

To be unadorned, unpersuasive, and unburdened by excess—
this is to dwell in non-possession within oneself.

The Dao of the Sage is non-possession within oneself,
so it flows without accumulation.
Thus the Sage has no hoard—
with hoarding comes insufficiency,
but without storing, there is abundance.

The Sage, having no hoard,
nourishes the world with the Way of abundance—
all turn to draw from it without depletion,
and so the more one gives to others, the more one possesses,
the more one bestows, the more one has.

For the Sage’s Dao is the Dao of Heaven itself—
Heaven’s Dao benefits without harm,
and thus the Sage’s Dao acts without contention.

Moreover, Heaven bestows beauty and benefit upon the world—
what harm could there be?

The Sage acts through non-action,
neither disrupting Heaven’s order
nor defying the nature of things—
what contention could there be?

This is the conclusion of the *De Jing*,
for virtue encompasses the Dao,
and the Dao encompasses Heaven.

To fail to comprehend Heaven is to fail to grasp the Sage—
thus the *Mystic Classic of the Dao and Virtue* ends here.

信言不美，美言不信。善者不辩，辩者不善。知者不博，博者不知。圣人无积，既以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多。天之道，利而不害；圣人之道，为而不争。

信言者，希言也，其出口也，淡乎其无味，故不美。」
